[Robert Penta]: Mr. Solicitor, the paper's already been disposed of, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Method Mass, former member of the Saugus party.

[Robert Penta]: I present this to you, and I believe all of you got a copy of, that's a three page document that was mailed out early this summer, pursuant to the request of Council Wendell Curran to explain the rationale behind having a local option filing piece of legislation regarding

[Robert Penta]: Community Preservation Act.

[Robert Penta]: When this Community Preservation Act was being sold to the folks here in the city of Medford, they were passing out pieces of literature such as this, talked about the Community Preservation Act.

[Robert Penta]: And on the back it says, communities submit annual reports to the state before receiving matching funds to ensure funds are properly spent.

[Robert Penta]: Matching funds.

[Robert Penta]: In 2002, which was the first year of the Community Preservation Act,

[Robert Penta]: For the first six years, cities and towns got 100% of their monies.

[Robert Penta]: And at that point in time, there was 113 communities.

[Robert Penta]: Now, in 2015, when the city of Medford voted for it, there's 156 communities.

[Robert Penta]: And all we're getting back this year is approximately 14.5%.

[Robert Penta]: And it's up to 178 communities.

[Robert Penta]: The problem that's existing, speaking to these communities, and a lot of the folks, these legislators in these communities, are beginning to realize now that the tax, the CPA tax, the community preservation tax that people are paying for is not being matched by the Commonwealth of Mass.

[Robert Penta]: We voted for this in 2015.

[Robert Penta]: Its first year of payment is now coming to us in 2017, this November.

[Robert Penta]: That's approximately $180,000, and we, the committee, collected $1.2 million, $500,000 of taxpayers' money.

[Robert Penta]: The legislation that I'm proposing is not to abolish the CPA, but rather to make it fair and equitable

[Robert Penta]: for the folks who voted for it, and especially for the people of Medford who believed, when they voted for this, that the Commonwealth was going to match dollar for dollar through the trust fund.

[Robert Penta]: And how it's being proposed right now is when you go to the Registry of Deeds, and whether it's a municipal lien or a tax on your real estate deeds, it's $10 or $20.

[Robert Penta]: What they're thinking right now is doubling it, and that would constitute another tax on people who buy and sell property.

[Robert Penta]: But putting that aside, until that happens,

[Robert Penta]: It was 2013 when it was then Governor DeVal Patrick who took $20 million, I believe, $25 million from the surplus money of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts just to meet the bare bones minimum of monies to go back to cities and towns in 2013.

[Robert Penta]: it was approximately 52% of the monies went back to the cities and towns.

[Robert Penta]: We're down now to 14%.

[Robert Penta]: And the law says the state cannot go any lower than 5%, which is sort of like outrageous because you're gonna keep taxing taxpayers in this community for something that's not being met.

[Robert Penta]: People believed when they voted for the Community Preservation Act that the Commonwealth of Mass would match that dollar for dollar, it was advertised as such, and it was stated as such.

[Robert Penta]: The two exceptions that I'm asking you folks to consider, and if you don't wanna vote on it tonight, that's all right, but I would appreciate it at least going to the city solicitor for the purposes of the following.

[Robert Penta]: I'm asking that there be a hold on the city going further on collecting any monies from taxpayers under the CPA Community Preservation Act.

[Robert Penta]: Because right now, it's not fair.

[Robert Penta]: You're telling the taxpayer that they have being taxed at 1.5% of their real estate value minus the first $100,000.

[Robert Penta]: But at the same time, they're not gonna be getting that dollar amount from the trust fund, from the Commonwealth of Mass back.

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, the second part of the resolve is that this is a five-year commitment, as you know, and it automatically renews itself after five years, unless there's a legislative question on the ballot not to renew it.

[Robert Penta]: This second option is to have it go on the ballot automatically to renew it.

[Robert Penta]: So it dies, it's like sunset legislation.

[Robert Penta]: It just dies at the end of five years.

[Robert Penta]: And if the community still wants to have it and they wanna go forward with it, they put it back on the ballot once again and the people can vote for it.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think it's anything that's detrimental to this community other than the fact you're gonna keep taxing rate payers in this community for something they're not getting their money's worth for and they're not getting the match for.

[Robert Penta]: And this greatly will impede

[Robert Penta]: This will greatly impede the concerns and the issues, whether it be for parks, historical pieces of property, low income housing, whatever the decision might be.

[Robert Penta]: Plus the fact I believe that they're paying somebody approximately $65,000.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. Pender, can I see that?

[Robert Penta]: Sure.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: I believe approximately right now somebody's getting paid, I believe if I understood when this came out a couple of months ago, somebody's gonna be paid approximately $65,000, $62,000, $149,000, okay?

[Robert Penta]: So we've collected $1,242,974 from the Medford taxpayers in this community.

[Robert Penta]: But all you're getting back from the Commonwealth of Mass is approximately $180,000.

[Robert Penta]: That's not fair.

[Robert Penta]: That's not the way this was supposed to be going.

[Robert Penta]: And now with more people coming on board, there's now 176 people applying for these monies from the Commonwealth.

[Robert Penta]: and having to go to the registry of deeds to double increase the taxes for municipal liens and for deed stamps that goes on our recordings, that's not fair.

[Robert Penta]: Just to meet the bare bones minimum.

[Robert Penta]: This year it's only 14%.

[Robert Penta]: It was reported in the local press earlier this year.

[Robert Penta]: You call the state house, they'll tell you the same thing.

[Robert Penta]: And you call, for which I had a long extensive conversation with the people in Boston, it's called the CPA,

[Robert Penta]: in Boston, their research people.

[Robert Penta]: This is not, this is not to say I or anyone opposed to this.

[Robert Penta]: What I'm opposed to is the inequity that this is now presented here within our community.

[Robert Penta]: And this inequity is not fair.

[Robert Penta]: Because people are believing.

[Robert Penta]: If you're only given $180,000 back on the $1.24 million, well, all we're asking to do is to put this on hold.

[Robert Penta]: Medford taxpayers do not have to pay for this until such time that the Commonwealth meets its obligation for the purposes of giving the reimbursement.

[Robert Penta]: That's what sold this program.

[Robert Penta]: That's what people voted for.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what they believed that they were getting, a match from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: And unfortunately, it's not existing, and it's not there.

[Robert Penta]: That should have been told, that should have been explained.

[Robert Penta]: And I think, Mr. Clerk, you can attest to the fact over 1,200 people never turned their ballot over in 2015 to vote yes or no on the question itself.

[Robert Penta]: So whether the people were not informed properly when they went to vote, or they just didn't want to vote, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: But that's an awful lot.

[Robert Penta]: And I just think it takes into the serious consideration of today, hard times, people, water connectivity fee, water and sewer taxes, your tax rate keeps going up.

[Robert Penta]: new police station, new fire station, a library.

[Robert Penta]: Where is this money coming from?

[Robert Penta]: And it's the most unfair way to go out and tax somebody right now on this issue.

[Robert Penta]: This is a state issue for which people went on

[Robert Penta]: I believe that this would be one way to at least mitigate until the Commonwealth of Mass gets its act together, either they're going to give the 100% back or they're not.

[Robert Penta]: Why should you deal with the idea that we'll, we guarantee 5% because that's what the law says?

[Robert Penta]: Well, what's 5%?

[Robert Penta]: That's meaningless.

[Robert Penta]: That is stupid.

[Robert Penta]: I'm more than happy to answer any questions.

[Robert Penta]: With all due respect, Rick, I have a folder here, and if you want to, I'll go over it with you, okay?

[Robert Penta]: This first came across the city council in 1991, okay?

[Robert Penta]: And in 1991, when this came out, when it became part of its first proposal, I think the then-Method City Council

[Robert Penta]: did not want to entertain it at the time because they felt it was another tax on the people, unfairly hitting them without having a say.

[Robert Penta]: And you only can put it in those four particular areas.

[Robert Penta]: Right now, okay, the people voted for it, we accept that, I got no problem with that.

[Robert Penta]: But how do you continue to go forward and tax the people when you're not even getting the money back?

[Robert Penta]: You're not even getting 50% of it back, you're only getting 14.5% of the money back.

[Robert Penta]: It's totally unfair.

[Robert Penta]: And if you go to these other cities and towns and you talk to them like I have, a lot of them are not realizing it until you go in there and you start reading the information that they have there and how it's broken down.

[Robert Penta]: And I got volumes on this.

[Robert Penta]: I don't sit home and read this for my health.

[Robert Penta]: I'm concerned about it.

[Robert Penta]: I think it's an end run on Proposition 2.5 if you continue to tax the people.

[Robert Penta]: at the way you're going.

[Robert Penta]: This is an alternative.

[Robert Penta]: It's a legitimate alternative that a city and town can pose, and until such time.

[Robert Penta]: And this is only good for five years, remember that, because the first year that you voted for was 15 to 16, and you had to get those numbers together, so you're not getting that money until 17.

[Robert Penta]: So the city of Medford is only gonna get it for four of the five years on the CPA.

[Robert Penta]: And then if it goes automatically after that, it'll be every year on and after that.

[Robert Penta]: But what I'm saying is at the end of the fifth year, Rick,

[Robert Penta]: the option would be that it ends, it becomes part of sunset legislation, and if the community wants to do it again, they put it on the ballot like they did the first time, and the people can vote it up or they can vote it down.

[Robert Penta]: That's what I'm asking here.

[Robert Penta]: Motion to sever the papers, Mr. President.

[Robert Penta]: It's a monster that's out of control.

[Robert Penta]: But unfortunately, the ratepayers, the taxpayers, are paying for it.

[Robert Penta]: And that's not fair.

[Robert Penta]: I don't believe that that is fair.

[Robert Penta]: So is Councilor Knight saying it's okay to tax the people without getting the adjust?

[Robert Penta]: redemption for why they voted for this?

[Robert Penta]: Okay, 14.555%.

[Robert Penta]: They can't even get to 50%, never mind 15%.

[Robert Penta]: It's just wrong.

[Robert Penta]: 2015, we voted, it was 29%.

[Robert Penta]: 29%, oh gosh.

[Robert Penta]: There's also a section here regarding you or anyone who's listening or anyone in this audience who decides to become a producer by giving something.

[Robert Penta]: Years in the past, we have paid deficits off with our free cash.

[Robert Penta]: So I believe you do have an option there, without getting into your recap, and at the same time.

[Robert Penta]: I would seriously question another portion of this transfer of why are you transferring $100,000 from the Office of Community Development, which is supposed to be the brainchild of bringing new business into this community, development into this community, meeting with business owners in this community, and being the partner in the arm with the Chamber of Commerce for which it doesn't seem to seem the light of day.

[Robert Penta]: So, Mr. President, I would suggest and I would hope that some member of the City Council would reflect upon that matter.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Pentez, Zero Summit Road, Medford Mass, former member of this ward.

[Robert Penta]: I'm glad to see this on the agenda this week because apparently last week when I introduced this before the council as to where this money went, apparently the mayor's office felt necessary to respond to it.

[Robert Penta]: Let's go back with a little bit of history here.

[Robert Penta]: On October 7th, 2014,

[Robert Penta]: when the mayor had the press release indicating that the contract had been signed.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: I'm a member of this August body.

[Robert Penta]: I come here tonight on two very important issues.

[Robert Penta]: that directly affect this Medford City Council and the taxpayers of our community.

[Robert Penta]: The first one is to address the issue of the CPA, the Community Preservation Act.

[Robert Penta]: As we know, when it was passed in November of 2015, it has a lifespan of five years from the date of its passage.

[Robert Penta]: It's now going to be just about into its second year with three years to go.

[Robert Penta]: The unfortunate part about this CPA is that at an election night some two years ago, almost 1,200 to 1,300 ballots

[Robert Penta]: were never acted upon, because a lot of people never turned the ballot over to vote for it.

[Robert Penta]: So whether it was going to pass or not, nobody even knew.

[Robert Penta]: Apparently, it did pass from those members that did vote.

[Robert Penta]: The unfortunate part about this particular act, and I'm going to draw the correlation to the connectivity fee, it's another tax being opposed upon the taxpayers of this community.

[Robert Penta]: But unfortunately, they're not getting that for which they voted for.

[Robert Penta]: The Enabling Act, which goes back to 2001 and 2002,

[Robert Penta]: addressed itself through the years, right up until this past year, to the fact that whatever and however the population count takes place, and however the tax valuation on assessed pieces of property here in the city of Medford, as in all cities and towns, determines the dollar amount that will come back from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: Now, we all know that for the past years, the Commonwealth has been having a tough time.

[Robert Penta]: So let's just go back to fiscal year 2013, the state gave back

[Robert Penta]: 52%.

[Robert Penta]: Fiscal year 2014, 31%.

[Robert Penta]: Fiscal year 2015, 29.7%.

[Robert Penta]: And this present past fiscal year 2016, they're at 18%.

[Robert Penta]: So for every dollar that every taxpayer here in the city of Medford has given up as it relates to the assessed evaluation at the 1.5%, the state will give back approximately 18%, which is nowhere near the dollar for dollar of 100%.

[Robert Penta]: I've spoken to members up at the legislature, and I've spoken to other cities and towns, where they feel to some degree that the taxpayer is not getting their real bank for the buck.

[Robert Penta]: You guys and gals are into this thing on the second year.

[Robert Penta]: You still have no program.

[Robert Penta]: There's still no designation where and how that money can be spent, whether it's for housing, affordable housing, parks and recreation, or historical values.

[Robert Penta]: Those are the three primary things.

[Robert Penta]: at a minimum of each one of those.

[Robert Penta]: So what I did is I looked at the law and I found it on page, it's section 18.

[Robert Penta]: Larry, he's not here when he comes back.

[Robert Penta]: And I think what I would want to do, and I'll pass one off for each of you.

[Robert Penta]: The intent of what I'd like to have is to have you as a city council consider the following.

[Robert Penta]: Since in fact the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is not paying back dollar for dollar as people

[Robert Penta]: have been led to believe because of the 158 cities and towns that now make up the CPA throughout the commonwealth.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think it's fair that we should keep paying, having our taxpayers pay their 1.5 share for the purposes of hopefully thinking they're going to get a match back.

[Robert Penta]: The proposal that I'm asking you as a council to do is to file a piece of legislation to amend

[Robert Penta]: Section 18, A and B. And in those two sections, they basically will say, if in fact the Commonwealth cannot meet its obligation of dollar for dollar for which the city of Medford at 1.5 is taxing their residents, then the city can suspend, by a vote of the city council, suspend any further collection of those taxes or that 1.5%, or you could also vote to reduce it down to 1%,

[Robert Penta]: until further notice, until the Commonwealth meets its obligation.

[Robert Penta]: That's the first part.

[Robert Penta]: And the second part, and I think it's very important that it's understood, that if this city and this council wants to not renew the CPA after its fifth year, at present, the only way you can do it is it becomes automatically taking place unless the city council, by a vote, puts the question on the ballot and the people vote for it all over again.

[Robert Penta]: My amendment to that portion states basically this, at the end of the fifth year, it automatically dies.

[Robert Penta]: If in fact, if in fact the people of this community and whoever the council might be at that time wishes to go forward and renew it again for another five years, then the question goes on the ballot.

[Robert Penta]: You are dealing with right now your second fiscal year on this CPA.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think anyone of you behind this rail have even been informed as to where and how that money is going to be spent.

[Robert Penta]: And there are provisos in there.

[Robert Penta]: It's a 12, it's a 12 page document.

[Robert Penta]: There are 18 sections to go with it.

[Robert Penta]: And in those 18 sections, it's very important to understand and to read.

[Robert Penta]: There's a great latitude that up to a nine member board or a commission has with that money.

[Robert Penta]: And you as a council haven't even been right into the picture.

[Robert Penta]: No public meetings and hearings have been held to find out where and how that money can be spent.

[Robert Penta]: While 30% can go to housing, historical and open space and recreational.

[Robert Penta]: The remaining 70% can be likewise used for the same, if not similar, situations that CPA will approve.

[Robert Penta]: I think you folks really need to take a deep, hard look at this particular law.

[Robert Penta]: Because as of July 1, as I said, once people start getting hit with a connectivity fee every other month, and then begin to realize that their 1.5%, which is in excess of $1 million, is being collected here at City Hall, and the state is not giving back the dollar for dollar, as people thought they did when they voted for this,

[Robert Penta]: That's two unfair taxes being placed upon taxpayers at the present time.

[Robert Penta]: The second thing I would like to talk about is the money that on October 7th, 2014, after many weeks of, excuse me, on October 7th in 2014, I don't know what's going on here, on October 7th,

[Robert Penta]: On 2014, after the then Medford City Council was reviewing Park Medford's application before the city of Medford, and Mayor McGlynn at that point in time signed the contract on October 7th, 2014, five additional addendums, five additional addendums were included into that Park Medford contract.

[Robert Penta]: If you're not going to get reimbursed from the state, then why take it out of the taxpayers of this community?

[Robert Penta]: And if you can't get it till the end of the fifth year, then so be it.

[Robert Penta]: It was a nice try.

[Robert Penta]: And if you look at the makeup on how they go, they go by a population standard, and they also go by a tax rate on the appraised property.

[Robert Penta]: And then it goes into a skew.

[Robert Penta]: It's a very complex situation.

[Robert Penta]: But if we're generating, Mr. President, over a million dollars a year or thereabouts, and we should be getting that back from the taxpayers of this community, we shouldn't even have to worry about historical things in this community.

[Robert Penta]: We shouldn't have to worry about our parks and open and recreation.

[Robert Penta]: We shouldn't have to worry about doing things in the area of public housing in that area or anything else that CPA would allow you to do.

[Robert Penta]: But we don't even know that.

[Robert Penta]: None of you know that because you haven't been told what it's going to be used for.

[Robert Penta]: You haven't even had any input.

[Robert Penta]: This is about as transparent as the number six.

[Robert Penta]: Any questions from anybody?

[Robert Penta]: Well, I'll be back in June and July and hopefully you'll have some kind of an answer to that because if this council feels that they don't want to go forward,

[Robert Penta]: then I will just go to the state legislature and ask some representative to pass it because a lot of these cities and towns, they're starting to feel it now because people are being taxed for something that they're not getting their money back on.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: The two sections that I'm referring to on the section 18, basically what the proposal says is as follows.

[Robert Penta]: At any time after imposition of the surcharge, the legislative body may approve by way of a vote to put on hold any local surcharge tax that cannot receive the matching dollar amount from the state upon population rank in real estate property tax levy calculation, as promulgated by Chapter 44B of the Massachusetts state statute.

[Robert Penta]: This allows citizen taxpayers to their fair return of their tax payments until such time

[Robert Penta]: Until such time, the state has the ability to match the intent and return amount as originally intended, as legislated, and voted upon.

[Robert Penta]: This is not killing it.

[Robert Penta]: All it's doing is, how can you tax somebody for something that you're not getting for what you're supposed to be getting?

[Robert Penta]: And the second part of it is basically saying, very simply, at the end of five years, after the date of approval, and after Sections 3 to 7, which is inclusive, have been accepted by the city or town,

[Robert Penta]: said sections shall come to an end, and the surcharge imposed for the past five years shall end.

[Robert Penta]: If the city or town want to continue on with sections three to seven, that's the inclusive part for which the city of Medford accepted, of the Preservation Act, said act shall once again be placed upon the ballot for the taxpayers to vote upon.

[Robert Penta]: Just the way it was the first time to be voted upon in November of 2015.

[Robert Penta]: That's fair, but to turn around and leave the law the way it is,

[Robert Penta]: If you want to take it off, you've got to go out there and get the signatures to have the people voted off.

[Robert Penta]: No, I don't think that's right.

[Robert Penta]: There's a sunset legislation.

[Robert Penta]: That's what it should be after five years.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's really working out that if it's working out that well, then maybe the taxpayers will vote it and maybe the taxpayers won't.

[Robert Penta]: But if you don't give them that chance in that choice, this will just keep going on at it for item.

[Robert Penta]: And it's a tax that'll never end because it doesn't have the opportunity to end.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, just as a point of inquiry.

[Robert Penta]: Point of inquiry, please.

[Robert Penta]: I understand they just received it and placed it on a file.

[Robert Penta]: I asked the council to review it so we could have a discussion.

[Robert Penta]: We could review it for the discussion for the July meeting.

[Robert Penta]: It is.

[Robert Penta]: I gave it to you.

[Robert Penta]: One is present and the other one is proposed.

[Robert Penta]: That's the section of the law.

[Robert Penta]: To the left on the top, it'll say present.

[Robert Penta]: And the next one down says proposed.

[Robert Penta]: If you want, I will send you a letter as it relates to that.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Sorry to interrupt you.

[Robert Penta]: Counsel Dello Russo.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, Bob Penton, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Two components on this particular issue.

[Robert Penta]: I'm glad it's coming up now.

[Robert Penta]: The first one is I think it's about $112,000.

[Robert Penta]: That's all that it would cost.

[Robert Penta]: This is what we were led to believe and what we were told when we changed over from the old metering system to the new one, to have a computerization program upstairs in the engineer's office.

[Robert Penta]: that would detect and identify anybody's house in the city of Medford where water would be constantly running or wherever leak might be.

[Robert Penta]: And on a daily basis, it would be reviewed, and that homeowner, taxpayer, ratepayer, would be identified either by a phone call or an email or what have you.

[Robert Penta]: That still hasn't taken place.

[Robert Penta]: And I think the next big thing you really need to address is that 10 years is already up relative to the meters that are in the houses.

[Robert Penta]: And that's going to have to take a second look on those batteries that are in there and just how accurate they are.

[Robert Penta]: So I would suggest that you make a resolution to investigate that with the Water and Soil Commissioner.

[Robert Penta]: What's their intent going forward as it relates to the accuracy of the batteries that are there, the meters that are there right now that are over 10 years?

[Robert Penta]: And second of all, why can't some money in that multimillion dollar surplus account be used to put that program

[Robert Penta]: You don't even have to have an employee.

[Robert Penta]: It's an automatic program that just spits it out on a daily basis.

[Robert Penta]: Someone just looks at it, and it's just, you know, as Jeannie Martin just said, you know, why keep hurting the taxpayer rate payer for no reason at all?

[Robert Penta]: These are just simple, common sense, everyday business practices that should be employed.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Penter, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of this August body.

[Robert Penta]: I come here tonight on two very important issues.

[Robert Penta]: that directly affect this Medford City Council and the taxpayers of our community.

[Robert Penta]: The first one is to address the issue of the CPA, the Community Preservation Act.

[Robert Penta]: As we know, when it was passed in November of 2015, it has a lifespan of five years from the date of its passage.

[Robert Penta]: It's now going to be just about into its second year with three years to go.

[Robert Penta]: The unfortunate part about this CPA is that at an election night some two years ago, almost 1,200 to 1,300 ballots

[Robert Penta]: were never acted upon because a lot of people never turned the ballot over to vote for it.

[Robert Penta]: So whether it was going to pass or not, nobody even knew.

[Robert Penta]: Apparently, it did pass from those members that did vote.

[Robert Penta]: The unfortunate part about this particular act, and I'm going to draw the correlation to the connectivity fee, it's another tax being opposed upon the taxpayers of this community.

[Robert Penta]: But unfortunately, they're not getting that for which they voted for.

[Robert Penta]: The Enabling Act, which goes back to 2001 and 2002,

[Robert Penta]: addressed itself through the years, right up until this past year, to the fact that whatever and however the population count takes place, and however the tax valuation on assessed pieces of property here in the city of Medford, as in all cities and towns, determines the dollar amount that will come back from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[Robert Penta]: Now, we all know that for the past years, the Commonwealth has been having a tough time.

[Robert Penta]: So let's just go back to fiscal year 2013, the state gave back

[Robert Penta]: 52 percent.

[Robert Penta]: Fiscal year 2014, 31 percent.

[Robert Penta]: Fiscal year 2015, 29.7 percent.

[Robert Penta]: And this present past fiscal year 2016, they were at 18 percent.

[Robert Penta]: So for every dollar that every taxpayer here in the city of Medford has given up as it relates to their assessed evaluation at the 1.5 percent, the state will give back approximately 18 percent, which is nowhere near the dollar for dollar of 100 percent.

[Robert Penta]: I've spoken to members up at the legislature and I've spoken to other cities and towns where they feel to some degree that the taxpayer is not getting their real bang for the buck.

[Robert Penta]: You guys and gals are into this thing on the second year.

[Robert Penta]: You still have no program.

[Robert Penta]: There's still no designation where and how that money can be spent, whether it's for housing, affordable housing, parks and recreation, or historical values.

[Robert Penta]: Those are the three primary things.

[Robert Penta]: at a minimum of each one of those.

[Robert Penta]: So what I did is I looked at the law and I found it on page, it's section 18.

[Robert Penta]: Larry, he's not here when he comes back.

[Robert Penta]: And I think what I would want to do, and I'll pass one off for each of you, the intent of what I'd like to have is to have you as a city council consider the following.

[Robert Penta]: Since in fact the Commonwealth of Massachusetts is not paying back dollar for dollar as people

[Robert Penta]: have been led to believe because of the 158 cities and towns that now make up the CPA throughout the commonwealth.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think it's fair that we should keep paying, having our taxpayers pay their 1.5 share for the purposes of hopefully thinking they're going to get a match back.

[Robert Penta]: The proposal that I'm asking you as a council to do is to file a piece of legislation to amend

[Robert Penta]: Section 18, A and B. And in those two sections, they basically will say, if in fact the Commonwealth cannot meet its obligation of dollar for dollar for which the city of Medford at 1.5 is taxing their residents, then the city can suspend, by a vote of the city council, suspend any further collection of those taxes or that 1.5%, or you could also vote to reduce it down to 1%,

[Robert Penta]: until further notice, until the Commonwealth meets its obligation.

[Robert Penta]: That's the first part.

[Robert Penta]: And the second part, and I think it's very important that it's understood, that if this city and this council wants to not renew the CPA after its fifth year, at present, the only way you can do it is it becomes automatically taking place unless the city council, by a vote, puts the question on the ballot and the people vote for it all over again.

[Robert Penta]: My amendment to that portion states basically this.

[Robert Penta]: At the end of the fifth year, it automatically dies.

[Robert Penta]: If, in fact, the people of this community and whoever the council might be at that time wishes to go forward and renew it again for another five years, then the question goes on the ballot.

[Robert Penta]: You are dealing with right now your second fiscal year on this CPA.

[Robert Penta]: I don't think any one of you behind this rail have even been informed as to where and how that money is going to be spent.

[Robert Penta]: And there are provisos in there.

[Robert Penta]: It's a 12-page document.

[Robert Penta]: There are 18 sections that go with it.

[Robert Penta]: And in those 18 sections, it's very important to understand and to read.

[Robert Penta]: There's a great latitude that up to a nine-member board or a commission has with that money.

[Robert Penta]: And you as a council haven't even been right into the picture.

[Robert Penta]: No public meetings and hearings have been held to find out where and how that money can be spent.

[Robert Penta]: While 30% can go to housing, historical, and open space and recreational, the remaining 70% can be likewise used for the same if not similar situations that CPA will approve.

[Robert Penta]: I think you folks really need to take a deep hard look at this particular law because as of July 4th, as I said, once people start getting hit with a connectivity fee every other month and then begin to realize that their 1.5%, which is in excess of a million dollars, is being collected here at City Hall,

[Robert Penta]: And the state is not giving back the dollar for dollar, as people thought they did when they voted for this.

[Robert Penta]: That's two unfair taxes being placed upon taxpayers at the present time.

[Robert Penta]: The second thing I would like to talk about is the money that, on October 7, 2014, after many weeks of failure.

[Robert Penta]: Excuse me.

[Robert Penta]: On October 7, 2014, I don't know what's going on here.

[Robert Penta]: on October 7th, 2014, after the then Medford City Council was reviewing Park Medford's application before the city of Medford, and Mayor McGlynn, at that point in time, signed the contract on October 7th, 2014.

[Robert Penta]: Five additional addendums were included into that Park Medford contract.

[Robert Penta]: And the one that stands out is the following, it says,

[Robert Penta]: He's recommending $250,000 of the revenue generated on a yearly basis to be dedicated to business district improvements.

[Robert Penta]: Now that's a result of the mayor making the comment after deliberating and discussing concerns issued by many business people in the community, the mayor is recommending the following.

[Robert Penta]: And he did that the same day he made that announcement.

[Robert Penta]: On December 18th, 2015,

[Robert Penta]: The Mayor sent out a notice to the members of the City Council, which basically said, in part, a representative of each business district will recommend to the Mayor some proposed uses.

[Robert Penta]: I respectfully request and recommend that the sum of $250,000 be transferred

[Robert Penta]: from the sale of real estate to be used for improvements to the five business districts with kiosks as I recommended earlier this year, which would have been effective calendar year 2016.

[Robert Penta]: would be used for improvements to business districts.

[Robert Penta]: This is the catch.

[Robert Penta]: The prior mayor made a commitment to that, Burke said.

[Robert Penta]: Each district right now is $100,000 behind.

[Robert Penta]: and what they should have been getting for the past two years, inclusive of Medford Square.

[Robert Penta]: Because that money should be designated in the real estate account.

[Robert Penta]: It's unfair to the business districts in this community.

[Robert Penta]: This is an election year.

[Robert Penta]: It was a nice try.

[Robert Penta]: And then it goes into a skew.

[Robert Penta]: We shouldn't have to worry about our parks and open and recreation.

[Robert Penta]: But we don't even know that.

[Robert Penta]: You haven't even had any input.

[Robert Penta]: Any questions from anybody?

[Robert Penta]: Well, I'll be back in July and hopefully you'll have some kind of an answer to that because if this council feels that they don't want to go forward,

[Robert Penta]: then I will just go to the state legislature and ask some representative to pass it, because a lot of these cities and towns, they're starting to feel it now, because people are being taxed for something that they're not getting their money back on.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: The two sections that I'm referring to on the section 18, basically what the proposal says is as follows.

[Robert Penta]: At any time after imposition of the surcharge, the legislative body may approve by way of a vote to put on hold any local surcharge tax that cannot receive the matching dollar amount from the state upon population rank in real estate property tax levy calculation, as promulgated by Chapter 44B of the Massachusetts state statute.

[Robert Penta]: This allows citizen taxpayers to their fair return of their tax payments until such time

[Robert Penta]: Until such time, the state has the ability to match the intent and return amount as originally intended, as legislated, and voted upon.

[Robert Penta]: This is not killing it.

[Robert Penta]: All it's doing is, how can you tax somebody for something that you're not getting for what you're supposed to be getting?

[Robert Penta]: And the second part of it is basically saying, very simply, at the end of five years, after the date of approval, and after Sections 3 to 7, which is inclusive, have been accepted by the city or town,

[Robert Penta]: said sections shall come to an end, and the surcharge imposed for the past five years shall end.

[Robert Penta]: If the city or town want to continue on with sections three to seven, that's the inclusive part for which the city of Medford accepted of the Preservation Act, said act shall once again be placed upon the ballot for the taxpayers to vote upon, just the way it was the first time to be voted upon in November of 2015.

[Robert Penta]: That's fair, but to turn around and leave the law the way it is,

[Robert Penta]: If you want to take it off, you've got to go out there and get the signatures to have the people voted off.

[Robert Penta]: No, I don't think that's right.

[Robert Penta]: There's a sunset legislation.

[Robert Penta]: That's what it should be after five years.

[Robert Penta]: And if it's really working out that if it's working out that well, then maybe the taxpayers will vote it and maybe the taxpayers won't.

[Robert Penta]: But if you don't give them that chance in that choice, this will just keep going on at it for an item.

[Robert Penta]: And it's a tax that'll never end because it doesn't have the opportunity to end.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: to have a computerization program upstairs in the engineer's office that would detect and identify anybody's house in the city of Medford where water would be constantly running or wherever a leak might be.

[Robert Penta]: It's an automatic program that just spits it out on a daily basis.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert M. Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of this August body.

[Robert Penta]: The reason why I'm up here is twofold, as the resolution indicates.

[Robert Penta]: I was a little befuddled when I got a copy of my water bill, and then I got a copy of the letter signed by the Board of Water and Soil Commissioners as it relates to what they call a baseline fee, which is, in essence, is a new tax on the rate payers here within this community.

[Robert Penta]: In their letter where they make an assessment of $24,000 is $24,483 is necessary.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know if this is a misprint on the spelling here.

[Robert Penta]: Pardon me?

[Robert Penta]: It's 24 million.

[Robert Penta]: No, that's the amount, I believe, of the total amount.

[Robert Penta]: I believe, if I understood it correctly from the chairman of the board, he alleged that it was approximately a $300,000 deficit on the sewer account.

[Robert Penta]: Now, this August, Marty, some weeks ago, voted to incorporate your enterprise fund, which includes the water and sewer account, as one.

[Robert Penta]: And by having the water and sewer count as one, that allows you, by right and by law, to make adjustments as it relates to profits and losses on either side.

[Robert Penta]: And at the present time, the new water bills that are going to be going out are going to be having an alleged 3% reduction in your water rate.

[Robert Penta]: But you're going to be charged what they call now a new connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: And this connectivity fee is addressing the fact that if you have whatever your line is that you have in your house, as it relates to your water and sewer hookup, from your house to the street, for which every taxpayer who owns the line.

[Robert Penta]: The fact of the matter is that the Water and Sewer Commission signed it, and the mayor of this community has allowed it, and likewise, this Medford City Council has done nothing to rebut it, for which you have a unique opportunity right now.

[Robert Penta]: The fact also presents itself with the issue that with this new combined water and sewer allowance,

[Robert Penta]: Why would you be reducing your water rate by 3% and now coming in and want to put a brand new tax on each and every other month, bimonthly, six times a year, ad infinitum, on Medford taxpayers, knowing that you have a surplus in excess of $8 million and you have a deficit in the sewer account

[Robert Penta]: for this 2018 year of $300,000.

[Robert Penta]: That does not make any sense.

[Robert Penta]: And the reason why it makes no sense is you will continuously keep going with a profit that you have, and your water and sewer count, and you have nothing presented before you as of the meeting that we had a month ago and as of tonight.

[Robert Penta]: Any major road construction, any major sidewalk construction, any street construction.

[Robert Penta]: The fact of the matter is, Mr. President, the connectivity tax that's going to be charged to the ratepayers.

[Robert Penta]: The Water and Sewer Commission comes under the auspices of the Mayor.

[Robert Penta]: They are appointed by the Mayor, and their recommendations go to the Mayor, and their recommendations, I'm quite sure, could not be holding to the taxpayers of this community at an outrageous rate.

[Robert Penta]: So a new tax and fee is being implemented on the taxpayers of this community.

[Robert Penta]: I'm glad you apologized on behalf of the council, because most recently, everybody got in their water and sewer bills

[Robert Penta]: a letter that indicated that they were going to be getting a new processing baseline rate, which I will call a tax.

[Robert Penta]: It's a new tax implemented on the citizens of this community on their water and sewer bill.

[Robert Penta]: It's called a connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: And you're going to be paying for that each and every other month, six times a year.

[Robert Penta]: Every taxpayer that owns their home owns from their house to the middle of the street.

[Robert Penta]: That's their pipe.

[Robert Penta]: That's what they're responsible for, and that's what they pay for.

[Robert Penta]: They make that connection already into the city's water and sewer line.

[Robert Penta]: The city is already charging you for water and sewer coming into your house through your pipe, through the connection.

[Robert Penta]: Now, the argument that's being used by the Water and Sewer Commission is

[Robert Penta]: We need to put this money aside, which is approximately $1 million a year, according to the type and size of your pipe coming into your house, connected to the street, to offset any future costs that might put the city in a negative position.

[Robert Penta]: My argument before this honorable body, I hope most of you can accept that word,

[Robert Penta]: Honorable, is the fact that the water and sewer account that we have right now is an $8.5 million surplus.

[Robert Penta]: You've merged, within the past two months, the water and sewer accounts of the Enterprise as to be one.

[Robert Penta]: If you are alleging, as the Water and Sewer Commission is alleging, there was a $300,000 deficit in the sewer account, but at the same time you're proposing a 3% reduction in the water rate for next year, the irony to that does not make any sense.

[Robert Penta]: Why?

[Robert Penta]: Because you have an $8 million surplus.

[Robert Penta]: You have them both now merged together.

[Robert Penta]: And the law allows you to take a surplus from one to offset the negative of another or vice versa.

[Robert Penta]: The other thing that this Water and Soil Commission has failed to do, it's under a 360 CMR 1100.

[Robert Penta]: It's a continuation of contract water supplies.

[Robert Penta]: And this came out in 1994.

[Robert Penta]: And it states the following.

[Robert Penta]: You incorporate a uniform rate or an alternative structure which provides incentives for water conservation and or is designed to ensure the affordability of water service to low and or fixed income people.

[Robert Penta]: You don't have that at the present time.

[Robert Penta]: That's never been brought up before the Water and Soil Commission to give that particular rate out.

[Robert Penta]: You don't have it.

[Robert Penta]: But if you're even going to get into the idea of the thought process of wanting to get into this, how do you justify the rates that are being proposed by the city?

[Robert Penta]: The rates being proposed by the city range anywhere from

[Robert Penta]: A residential house up to 3 quarters of an inch would be $51.66 a year.

[Robert Penta]: Now, you may say it's only $51.

[Robert Penta]: But you know something?

[Robert Penta]: $51 to some people is a lot of money, especially if you want a fixed income.

[Robert Penta]: And if you have a one-inch line coming into your house, it's $141 a year.

[Robert Penta]: Take that and add it on to the CPA tax, for which you're not even going to get reimbursed by the state on.

[Robert Penta]: That is another $50, $60 a year.

[Robert Penta]: And now you're almost up to over $150, $200 a year.

[Robert Penta]: Your taxes each and every year continuously keep going up.

[Robert Penta]: It's absolutely unfair for the city to even entertain or engage itself in a connectivity fee tax every other month when you're sitting on that kind of a profit.

[Robert Penta]: Now, if you want to be realistic and look at this thing and say, OK, maybe we should do like some other cities and towns, the community of Melrose, your sister next door, they have a one-time fee.

[Robert Penta]: And it's at the discretion of the director of public works.

[Robert Penta]: It's a one-time fee of $50.

[Robert Penta]: And if you're building a new house and it's a first-time connection, so be it.

[Robert Penta]: If you're rebuilding your house and you have to make a reconnection, that reconnection is either $50 and or at the discretion

[Robert Penta]: of the Director of Public Works, because if you're the same owner, it could be abated.

[Robert Penta]: It just doesn't make any sense.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any sense because you, as the Medford City Council, are supposed to be looking out for the best financial interests of this community.

[Robert Penta]: And the only way you can seem to do it right now, at least through the majority of you, if you so choose, is you just hold this budget in abeyance until the mayor comes forward and indicates how can you keep going out and making these charges against Medford taxpayers and ratepayers.

[Robert Penta]: Let's flip over to the second part, to the hotel.

[Robert Penta]: You have a hotel proposal that you haven't even sat down, hasn't even been discussed, and there the mayor of this community in the State of the City address in February says this is going to be up and running by the fall of 2019.

[Robert Penta]: You haven't had a discussion either with the contractor who's only been around since 2013.

[Robert Penta]: You don't even know what the taxes is going to be.

[Robert Penta]: And the best part about this hotel, you need city and state land to be taken to accommodate the parking that's necessary for this proposed hotel.

[Robert Penta]: Here's your time to discuss it during the budget.

[Robert Penta]: And if you don't discuss it, why give the vote out?

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any sense.

[Robert Penta]: It's unfortunate under this form of government that this mayor who said she was going to be transparent and would have someone here each and every week to listen and to discuss these issues, there's nobody here.

[Robert Penta]: You're lucky if that person's been here twice in the two years that it's been here.

[Robert Penta]: And what doesn't make sense is how can you go back and keep telling Mr. and Mrs. Taxpayer that this is only a small little dollar amount, especially when you're dealing with a surplus.

[Robert Penta]: You've got $9 million in your free cash or thereabouts.

[Robert Penta]: But nobody around here has discussed your $29 million in an unfunded liability.

[Robert Penta]: How are you going to address that?

[Robert Penta]: And is this new connectivity charge going to be able to be used to offset salaries and wages of employees in that department, pension system funds?

[Robert Penta]: These are the questions you need to ask.

[Robert Penta]: And the low and moderate income, fixed income people don't even have a break on this.

[Robert Penta]: So while you think you're making the taxpayer feel good because you're lowering his water rate by 3%, you're charging him in excess of the 3% by having a bimonthly, six times a year, new tax being placed upon him.

[Robert Penta]: And the line that should really get you in every single ratepayer is this.

[Robert Penta]: It says the base rate is not a tax, nor is it an additional charge in which residents pay for water and sewer services.

[Robert Penta]: Well, you tell me what it is.

[Robert Penta]: You tell me, Mr. President, what it is.

[Robert Penta]: If it's not a tax, okay, if it's not a fee, and if it's not for water and sewer services, well, why am I paying a connectivity fee to let that water go through that pipe that comes into the pipe that I own, that comes into my house, that you charge me water and sewer taxes on?

[Robert Penta]: I respectfully ask this Medford City Council to ask this mayor, you hold up this question and remove this connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: It's an unfair tax, it's unnecessary, and it does not do good for the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: I'm more than happy to answer any questions.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: How you would rebut it is you would tell the mayor that we're not voting for your budget until you tell the Water and Sewer commissioners to roll back that fee.

[Robert Penta]: You justify $8.5 million sitting there and justify telling the taxpayers you're going to generate another million dollars plus a year with this connectivity fee, and you don't even have a program set aside.

[Robert Penta]: Look at every street.

[Robert Penta]: Look at all the streets that are waiting to be done.

[Robert Penta]: Look at the potholes that can't get done.

[Robert Penta]: Look at Evans Street that's been promised for almost two years they were going to get done when the water main broke.

[Robert Penta]: We could just go on and on and on with this.

[Robert Penta]: You can't keep charging the taxpayers of this community for something, especially when you're sitting on millions of dollars in a surplus in this particular account.

[Robert Penta]: We're reducing the water rate, Madam Chairperson, we're reducing the water rate by 3%.

[Robert Penta]: So if you have a $24 million cost, whatever it is, I think that's what you said, Mr. President, for the cost of coming in this year, and inclusive of that cost is water and sewer charges, because it's coming in, and we all know that your sewer charge is at 121% of your water.

[Robert Penta]: So if the city already knows that they're going to be operating at a $300,000 loss, why wouldn't you just take the money from your $8.5 million profit rather than go out and tell the people we're going to charge you for a connectivity fee and have the audacity to put in a letter that's got nothing to do with water and sewer services?

[Robert Penta]: What do you think, people are stupid?

[Robert Penta]: I'm not stupid.

[Robert Penta]: You know, I love this city, and I'll do anything to make it right.

[Robert Penta]: But when I see stuff like this, this really gets to me, all right?

[Robert Penta]: And it should get to every one of you members of the City Council.

[Robert Penta]: Because it's not right, it's not fair, and you can't even take care of people on fixed incomes, you know, allowing you to do this.

[Robert Penta]: You haven't even discussed that.

[Robert Penta]: Where's the Water and Soil Commissioner on that?

[Robert Penta]: Didn't mean TL, Mr. President, but you know something?

[Robert Penta]: When you sit here all night and you watch what's going on here and you're being played to wait till the end of the night, I get upset.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: But every dog has its day.

[Robert Penta]: Remember that.

[Robert Penta]: There's an election coming up and I hope people remember that.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert M. Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of this August party.

[Robert Penta]: The reason why I'm up here is twofold, as the resolution indicates.

[Robert Penta]: I was a little befuddled when I got a copy of my water bill, and then I got a copy of the letter signed by the Board of Water and Soil Commissioners as it relates to what they call a baseline fee, which is, in essence, is a new tax on the rate payers here within this community.

[Robert Penta]: In their letter, where they make an assessment of $24,000, is $24,483 is necessary.

[Robert Penta]: I don't know if this is a misprint on the spelling here.

[Robert Penta]: Pardon me?

[Robert Penta]: It's $24 million.

[Robert Penta]: No, that's the amount, I believe, of the total amount.

[Robert Penta]: I believe, if I understood it correctly from the chairman of the board, he alleged that it was approximately a $300,000 deficit on the sewer account.

[Robert Penta]: Now, this August, Marty, some weeks ago, voted to incorporate your enterprise fund, which includes the water and sewer account, as one.

[Robert Penta]: And by having the water and sewer count as one, that allows you, by right and by law, to make adjustments as it relates to profits and losses on either side.

[Robert Penta]: And at the present time, the new water bills that are going to be going up are going to be having an alleged 3% reduction in your water rate.

[Robert Penta]: but you're going to be charged what they call now a new connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: And this connectivity fee is addressing the fact that if you have whatever your line is that you have in your house, as it relates to your water and sewer hookup, from your house to the street, for which every taxpayer who owns the property owns the line.

[Robert Penta]: My records that I have dating back when I was in the council go back to 2010.

[Robert Penta]: when this proposal was made.

[Robert Penta]: And the very first proposal was made by David Hatzell, who was a city engineer some multiple years ago, 20 years ago, when he got involved in an I&I program that saved the city approximately a million gallons of water per day.

[Robert Penta]: Now, subsequent to that period of time, up until now, you've had loans, grant loans, from the MWRA that either were interest-free or minimum

[Robert Penta]: and some of them have ranged anywhere from $5 million to $3.5 million.

[Robert Penta]: The sad part about all of this, as Councilor Marksley alluded to, is the fact that you have unaccounted for water in this city, which ranges anywhere from 17, 18, 19, 20%.

[Robert Penta]: Nobody really has the final handle on that.

[Robert Penta]: But there are a lot of services in this community that are using our water for which taxpayers, city taxpayers are paying for, and that's unfair too.

[Robert Penta]: Now you folks just passed, I believe it was last week, the combining of your water and sewer accounts together.

[Robert Penta]: And I would suggest as an addendum to the resolution tonight, that a request be made to your city solicitor for the purposes of, since these have now been merged together, can those monies be used for any other enterprises or any other general expenditures within your enterprise fund?

[Robert Penta]: checking this out with other states, and every state does it different as it relates to enterprise funds, I think it's important to note, because if you have merged these two accounts together financially, and where one has a deficit in one year and one might have an excess in another year, it would be very

[Robert Penta]: convenient to offset one from the other.

[Robert Penta]: Again, I don't know.

[Robert Penta]: Every state does it different.

[Robert Penta]: So I think it would behoove you to check this out with your city solicitor as to how the methods merging of its water and sewer account is used as it relates to any other fund, general fund, enterprise funds, general revenue account funds that the city has, because in some states, they're allowed to take the excess profit.

[Robert Penta]: Also, you folks, just as a reminder, what took place last week,

[Robert Penta]: You were told at a meeting by Mr. Fox and by the chairman of the Water and Sewer Commission that the water rates are going to be reduced by approximately 3% this year, by approximately 3%.

[Robert Penta]: But at the same time, they're going to be introducing what they call a connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: And the connectivity fee is going to be going toward pipe size coming into your house, anywhere from a half inch up to 10 inches, depending whether you're residential or whether you're a commercial.

[Robert Penta]: And I think it's important to note that I think the chairman of the board said, well, we're not going to call it connectivity.

[Robert Penta]: We're going to call it baseline.

[Robert Penta]: But baseline already has its position.

[Robert Penta]: It has its position within the Mass General Laws under chapter 60.

[Robert Penta]: Where is it here?

[Robert Penta]: It's under chapter 65, chapter 165, section 2B, where it talks about baseline having an effect

[Robert Penta]: on a city or town which does not reflect upon connectivity.

[Robert Penta]: It goes against large consumer use or the rate of use in the community, whether it goes up or down.

[Robert Penta]: And I think that's something you as a council need to get, that's got to be corrected.

[Robert Penta]: And hopefully, I wish somebody from the Water and Sewer Department were here, chairman or otherwise, to explain this connectivity fee because I think as we all know, people are looking at it as another fee.

[Robert Penta]: How can you be charging another fee on a bimonthly basis when in fact,

[Robert Penta]: your water rates are going down by 3%.

[Robert Penta]: But since, in fact, I believe it was alleged that there is a deficit on the sewer department side, and now with the merging of the water and sewer accounts together, I think the second question needs to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: Can the excess from one, which would be the revenue, the profit, or the excess money on that, can you use it to offset the deficit from one to the other?

[Robert Penta]: Because if you look at the merging of the two,

[Robert Penta]: It incorporates all your vehicles.

[Robert Penta]: It incorporates your employees, equipment, salaries, and everything else that goes along with it.

[Robert Penta]: So I think there is a benefit to what Councilor Marks is alluding.

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, I don't think that the Medford taxpayer, knowing that there's over $7.5 million in excess account in this particular area, should be taken for the ride of saying, hey,

[Robert Penta]: You know, if you're right, Councilor Markson, it's up to 21%.

[Robert Penta]: But whatever it is, there should be a full accounting of the water and the metering of the water and how it's being distributed here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: You know, we all run businesses.

[Robert Penta]: Probably some people use more water than others.

[Robert Penta]: But if you're going to go that route and you're going to start charging people for the size of their water meter coming in, water pipe coming in,

[Robert Penta]: You know, that's going to have a profound effect on each and every taxpayer here in the city of Medford, because that's going to be on a bimonthly charge.

[Robert Penta]: And as the enterprise fund will tell you, and all you have to do is look up other states and other cities and towns and how the merging of enterprise funds, what you can and cannot do with them.

[Robert Penta]: And it's a whole host of activities.

[Robert Penta]: For example, in Winchester, they have an enterprise fund, but they also have an enterprise activity account fund.

[Robert Penta]: And again, trying to get a handle on that.

[Robert Penta]: It also deals with recreation.

[Robert Penta]: and a whole host of other things.

[Robert Penta]: Granted, Winchester's a town and not a city, but it's the intent and it's the purpose of the legislation and the merger that is written.

[Robert Penta]: So I would suggest that one of you make this request of the city solicitor, just what, in fact, does this enterprise fund, now that it's merged together, water and sewer, allow the city of Medford to do with those monies?

[Robert Penta]: Can they transfer them?

[Robert Penta]: Can they merge them?

[Robert Penta]: Can they be used to offset?

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't seem logical or with any sense of common sense that you could be having a profit in the water side and you have a deficit on the sewer side.

[Robert Penta]: But to this day, you haven't been able to offset it.

[Robert Penta]: But what you're going to be doing is charging a connectivity fee on your pipeline coming in, which supposedly will offset the sewer charge according to what was told you last week.

[Robert Penta]: But at the same time, you're going to be reducing your water rate by 3%.

[Robert Penta]: It's a lot for people to understand.

[Robert Penta]: It doesn't make any sense at all, especially when you're sitting on seven and a half million dollars, whether you want to call it surplus, reserve, or whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: This is a huge issue that's before you right now.

[Robert Penta]: Other than your tax bill, it's the next biggest thing that the citizen of this community has to deal with.

[Robert Penta]: And just for an example, relative to a connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: And your town of Stoneham, which is right across the border, they just have a one-time connectivity charge.

[Robert Penta]: New house going up, new resident, new line going in, $50 for a residential unit, up to one to five units.

[Robert Penta]: And anything over that in a commercial, it's $1,000 hookup.

[Robert Penta]: And that's what it might be.

[Robert Penta]: One-inch service is $500.

[Robert Penta]: A one- to two-inch service is $750.

[Robert Penta]: And a two-inch service or above is $1,000.

[Robert Penta]: Numbers are a lot lower than what's being proposed here.

[Robert Penta]: It's a one-time fee, and that fee is at the discretion of the Director of Public Works and the City of Stoneham.

[Robert Penta]: Every city and town does it different.

[Robert Penta]: I understand that.

[Robert Penta]: But it's hard to explain to the Mr. and Mrs. Medford resident that when you just gave them a new tax increase in their bill, when you're hitting them with a CPA tax, Community Preservation Act tax, for which the Commonwealth will not even meet its obligation to match the dollar for dollar that each rate payer is paying,

[Robert Penta]: Because that's what the people voted on under that assumption.

[Robert Penta]: And now you may be hitting them with a connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: It's just not fair.

[Robert Penta]: So as Councilor Marks has alluded to, and hopefully the council will go along with it, I really think you need a complete assessment of all the water, all the sewer usage here in the city of Metro to get a better handle as it relates to what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: And it's just a shame that your Water and Sewer Commissioners do not appear before this board to explain this.

[Robert Penta]: This is really an involved process.

[Robert Penta]: But you're once again hitting the rate payers with another fee.

[Robert Penta]: And I would assume that that would be very hard to explain, very hard to explain when you're sitting on $7.5 million profit at the present time.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you.

[Robert Penta]: On the motion by Councilor Marks.

[Robert Penta]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Robert Penta]: My name is Robert Pantazero, Summit Road, Medford, Mass.

[Robert Penta]: Former member of the Saugus party.

[Robert Penta]: My records that I have dating back when I was in the council go back to 2010.

[Robert Penta]: when this proposal was made.

[Robert Penta]: And the very first proposal was made by David Hadsall, who was a city engineer some multiple years ago, 20 years ago, when he got involved in an I&I program that saved the city approximately a million gallons of water per day.

[Robert Penta]: Now, subsequent to that period of time, up until now, you've had loans, grant loans, from the MWRA that either were interest-free or minimum.

[Robert Penta]: and some of them have ranged anywhere from $5 million to $3.5 million.

[Robert Penta]: The sad part about all of this, as Councilor Marx has alluded to, is the fact that you have unaccounted for water in this city, which ranges anywhere from 17, 18, 19, 20%.

[Robert Penta]: Nobody really has the final handle on that.

[Robert Penta]: But there are a lot of services in this community that are using our water for which taxpayers, city taxpayers are paying for, and that's unfair too.

[Robert Penta]: Now you folks just passed, I believe it was last week, the combining of your water and sewer accounts together.

[Robert Penta]: And I would suggest as an addendum to the resolution tonight that a request be made to your city solicitor for the purposes of, since these have now been merged together, can those monies be used for any other enterprises or any other general expenditures within your enterprise fund?

[Robert Penta]: checking this out with other states, and every state does it different as it relates to enterprise funds, I think it's important to note, because if you have merged these two accounts together financially, and where one has a deficit in one year and one might have an excess in another year, it would be very

[Robert Penta]: convenient to offset one from the other.

[Robert Penta]: Again, I don't know, every state does it different.

[Robert Penta]: So I think it would behoove you to check this out with your city solicitor as to how the methods merging of its water and sewer account is used as it relates to any other fund, general fund, enterprise funds, general revenue account funds that the city has, because in some states they're allowed to take the excess profit.

[Robert Penta]: Also, you folks, just as a reminder, what took place last week,

[Robert Penta]: You were told at a meeting by Mr. Fox and by the chairman of the Water and Sewer Commission that the water rates are going to be reduced by approximately 3% this year, by approximately 3%.

[Robert Penta]: But at the same time, they're going to be introducing what they call a connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: And the connectivity fee is going to be going toward pipe size coming into your house, anywhere from a half inch up to 10 inches, depending whether you're residential or whether you're a commercial.

[Robert Penta]: And I think it's important to note that I think the chairman of the board said, well, we're not going to call it connectivity.

[Robert Penta]: We're going to call it baseline.

[Robert Penta]: But baseline already has its position.

[Robert Penta]: It has its position within the Mass General Laws under chapter 60.

[Robert Penta]: Where is it here?

[Robert Penta]: It's under chapter 65, chapter 165, section 2B, where it talks about baseline having an effect

[Robert Penta]: on a city or town which does not reflect upon connectivity.

[Robert Penta]: It goes against large consumer use or the rate of use in the community, whether it goes up or down.

[Robert Penta]: And I think that's something you as a council need to get, that's got to be corrected.

[Robert Penta]: And hopefully, I wish somebody from the Water and Sewer Department were here, chairman or otherwise, to explain this connectivity fee.

[Robert Penta]: Because I think as we all know, people are looking at it as another fee.

[Robert Penta]: How can you be charging another fee on a bimonthly basis when in fact,

[Robert Penta]: your water rates are going down by 3%.

[Robert Penta]: But since, in fact, I believe it was alleged that there is a deficit on the sewer department side, and now with the merging of the water and sewer accounts together, I think the second question needs to be asked.

[Robert Penta]: Can the excess from one, which would be the revenue, the profit, or the excess money on that, can you use it to offset the deficit from one to the other?

[Robert Penta]: Because if you look at the merging of the two,

[Robert Penta]: It incorporates all your vehicles.

[Robert Penta]: It incorporates your employees, equipment, salaries, and everything else that goes along with it.

[Robert Penta]: So I think there is a benefit to what Councilor Marks is alluding.

[Robert Penta]: But more importantly, I don't think that the Medford taxpayer, knowing that there's over $7.5 million in excess account in this particular area, should be taken for the ride of saying, hey, if you're right, Councilor Marks, and it's up to 21%, but whatever it is,

[Robert Penta]: There should be a full accounting of the water and the metering of the water, and how it's being distributed here in the city of Medford.

[Robert Penta]: We all run businesses.

[Robert Penta]: Probably some people use more water than others.

[Robert Penta]: Number one, I would be opposed to this bill if I was sitting on that side of the rail, because number one, I think this is an infringement upon the free enterprise system.

[Robert Penta]: The Board of Health has a job to do.

[Robert Penta]: They go out there, they review the product of the restaurant,

[Robert Penta]: or whatever it might be, that's their job.

[Robert Penta]: And for them to start taking an arbitrary and capricious action by placing a, A, B, or C on the type of business that's taking place, who are they?

[Robert Penta]: They don't frequent that business.

[Robert Penta]: And I think it would lead a very, uh, it would, it would skew.

[Robert Penta]: the public to go into a certain direction to say one business might be better than another.

[Robert Penta]: You know, this is just as bad as municipal aggregation.

[Robert Penta]: You know, you're asking city government to get involved in people's lives, their personal lives, and in this situation, their personal life is a personal business.

[Robert Penta]: When they go and do their job, and they review a restaurant, and they get a certificate on there that says it's been approved, whether it's a milk license, a common ventures license, or any kind of food product license, that's the city or the town telling you that that place has passed the test.

[Robert Penta]: They don't need to have a rating system.

[Robert Penta]: When you start getting into a rating system, well, maybe we should have departments come down here and rate you guys and girls on the performance of your jobs, OK?

[Robert Penta]: You're really crossing over the line on something like this.

[Robert Penta]: You have a department that does its job.

[Robert Penta]: And its job is to go out there and to ensure that the food product in a business is safe, it's good to eat,

[Robert Penta]: And so be it.

[Robert Penta]: And now if you're going to start putting a rating system on it, I think you're really crossing over the line.

[Robert Penta]: You know, people spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to go into a food business.

[Robert Penta]: And it's a personality conflict.

[Robert Penta]: However it is, they go there, they do their job, but their business takes care of itself.

[Robert Penta]: Their product sold to the public will take care of itself.

[Robert Penta]: We don't need any city administration telling a business person that owns a restaurant how they should be rated by this city.

[Robert Penta]: Robert Penta, Zero Summit Road, Medford, Mass., former member of the circus party.

[Robert Penta]: You know, a city that forgets about its history won't have any history.

[Robert Penta]: And at the rate we're going in the city right now, the way developers have this opportunity to come in here, seize a piece of property, build upon it, and then take off and make a profit on it.

[Robert Penta]: perfect example is Luminaires on Locust Street.

[Robert Penta]: Puts the building up, he's there a year, sells it for $61 million, and he's gone.

[Robert Penta]: South Boston, if you've been following this for the last two weeks, is a perfect example where the residents have gotten together on the development of a gentleman who wants to come in there and take over a piece of property that's perfectly zoned for what he wants to do, but the neighbors are opposed to it because it doesn't fit the character of the neighborhood.

[Robert Penta]: The state representative from that area, Michael Flaherty, has proposed a piece of legislation, and I believe he's doing it tomorrow morning.

[Robert Penta]: He's proposing a piece of legislation that the character of the neighborhood has to be kept in line for that for which is there.

[Robert Penta]: It cannot be made to look anything different or obnoxious or something that's not satisfying to the public or to the people in that neighborhood.

[Robert Penta]: That's probably the best thing because he's not the real person that should be here for the city.

[Robert Penta]: Does that mean now fire and police are going to be separated?

[Robert Penta]: Or is it not going to be separated?

[Robert Penta]: You haven't even gotten a final answer as it relates to the police department going forward.

[Robert Penta]: If they take down the station over there for the training tower, for the fire department, and you're going to go to a regional location, that's going to put the fire department at issue for backup because they're going to have to send their truck and their men to that regional location.

[Robert Penta]: A public safety issue.

[Robert Penta]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[Robert Penta]: Mr. President, the Medford Public Schools

[Robert Penta]: as in the commentary from the superintendent, would like to meet with state and local governments as it relates to current code, including fire doors, fire alarms, sprinkler systems, and safety conditions.

[Robert Penta]: All things that right now are in potential violation are, if not in violation, as we presently speak.

[Robert Penta]: After the new, I believe we all can remember, after the new science labs were built, there was a major problem for almost a year where a fire person had to be up at the high school because the fire system, the fire alarm system didn't work as it related to something happened, whether through the electrical department or what have you.

[Robert Penta]: Then, if I understand this correctly,

[Robert Penta]: And Mr. Belson's commentary, and I agree with you a hundred percent.

[Robert Penta]: You said any decision regarding the specific projects and the financial commitments would be developed over time and after multiple meetings within city government and at the state level.

[Robert Penta]: Well, at least he's got the ability to understand and recognize that city government officials need to sit down and discuss it much more than the person who calls herself the mayor of this community.

[Robert Penta]: This is a big issue, whether you wanna realize it or not.

[Robert Penta]: The building is 50 years old.

[Robert Penta]: You're talking about the same fire and police station that's down there right now.

[Robert Penta]: Maintenance didn't take place in the building.

[Robert Penta]: Now a lot of these things are maintenance driven, whether they be fire, whether they be the windows, whether they be the boiler or what have you, the asbestos.

[Robert Penta]: It's a big building.

[Robert Penta]: I think it's four and a half miles long, Mr. Superintendent.

[Robert Penta]: 550,000 square feet, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: It was built at a time to be a college campus type of a school.

[Robert Penta]: But that's not the point.

[Robert Penta]: You're getting a lot of this all at once.

[Robert Penta]: Maybe, to some degree, maybe, whether it's the cafeteria or whatever the auditorium is, maybe if you just stuck to the real desperate needs that the building has on a slow annual basis, you can look at these other things and put them into the budget.

[Robert Penta]: Let me just remind you, and I'll just leave you with this last thought.

[Robert Penta]: Just look at the city of Somerville.

[Robert Penta]: Look at all the development that's taken place over there.

[Robert Penta]: All the development.

[Robert Penta]: Okay.

[Robert Penta]: Many, many more jobs and their taxes keep on going up.

[Robert Penta]: You don't have that opportunity here in the city of Medford, because if we're going to follow the mainstream of some of them and taxing the citizens of this community to pay for bond indebtedness that you can't afford.

[Robert Penta]: And as council Marks and others alluded to, you're going to get yourself into a proposition two and a half override.

[Robert Penta]: It'll lose everyone behind this council.

[Robert Penta]: I guarantee you will lose if you'll be supportive of that.

[Robert Penta]: If you're serving at that point in time.
