[Robert Penta]: And I'm saying to myself, well, wait a minute.

[Robert Penta]: What is this all about?

[Robert Penta]: This is not having a full-fledged studio that's equipped on its own merits at its own location.

[Robert Penta]: Then I started to think about this thing even more.

[Robert Penta]: And I'm saying to myself, we have a concern here.

[Robert Penta]: We're putting channel-free equipment into Medford City Hall.

[Robert Penta]: And by putting Channel 3 equipment into Medford City Hall, are we talking about having a liability issue here?

[Robert Penta]: Are we talking about the equipment here in City Hall?

[Robert Penta]: Are we talking about the access to City Hall?

[Robert Penta]: The keys and who would have keys to City Hall?

[Robert Penta]: Who would be coming into City Hall if, in fact, something were to go wrong in the transmission from City Hall to 32 Riverside Avenue?

[Robert Penta]: And there's a whole host of questions here.

[Robert Penta]: And the city has a liability policy as it relates to being a self-insured.

[Robert Penta]: Now, we all know that Channel 3 is a separate private nonprofit corporation.

[Robert Penta]: So, I mean, we have two separate entities here running around.

[Robert Penta]: We were also told at that point in time that there was, I believe, less than $100,000 operating budget that they were operating in, but there is another budget for whatever that might be worth.

[Robert Penta]: So I tried to get down there on two separate occasions on Riverside Avenue.

[Robert Penta]: Both times I couldn't get in.

[Robert Penta]: Both times the door was locked, but on one particular day,

[Robert Penta]: The paper was down, I did have a chance to look in, and it didn't look like there was hardly any work, if any work at all was taking place down there.

[Robert Penta]: Now this goes back to March of this year.

[Robert Penta]: So now we have a station manager that's getting paid.

[Robert Penta]: We have no transmission, no broadcasting coming forward.

[Robert Penta]: We have, for whatever the reason might be, if in fact the city of Medford is now being a part of whatever Channel 3 is going to be involved with, if the mayor is doing this, I have no idea why Channel 3 would even be here.

[Robert Penta]: and entertaining City Hall, but more importantly, why would they even want to stay on Riverside Avenue with no access to cable television, Verizon or Comcast?

[Robert Penta]: You know, poor choice, they've been around, they know the situation, they know what Medford Square is about, they know what Riverside Ave is all about, and that was a poor choice to go there, especially being in the business for, they're not novice, these people that are working there, and they're a part of Channel 3, they've been around for a while, they know what's going on.

[Robert Penta]: And since they know what's going on, the sad part about this is they've got themselves locked into a contract for which I would assume, I would hope that they would be able to get out of.

[Robert Penta]: And even if they had to get sued, who cares about getting sued?

[Robert Penta]: Look at the time that you're costing the city, the taxpayers, each of the rate payers, each and every cable bill are paying for something.

[Robert Penta]: You're paying for station manager that has no job to do because there's nothing being programmed.

[Robert Penta]: There's nothing being taped.

[Robert Penta]: And then it dawned on me yesterday while we were at the cemetery and we were listening to the speeches being made and watching the people that were there and the observance, where is all this portable equipment?

[Robert Penta]: The portable equipment that Channel 3 has had through the years from the thousands and thousands and thousands of dollars that subscribers have not only paid, but the city of Medford has transferred over to Channel 3 through the years.

[Robert Penta]: They could have had people out there with portable cameras doing the portable televising of it.

[Robert Penta]: And then, if in fact, and when they do come back on, that they would have a whole host of things to put on, the Memorial Day service, graduations, whatever it might be.

[Robert Penta]: You don't see any of that around.

[Robert Penta]: And then we were told there's 10 board of directors.

[Robert Penta]: I have no idea who the board of directors are, and I would hope they would come forward and let us know who these board of directors are so we could get a handle on what the makeup of the board is.

[Robert Penta]: And then, I believe one of the situations that came up, going back and reviewing Judge Jackson's report, that the city paid over $15,000 on, Melanson and Heath, the city's auditor, on one particular year, going back, I believe it was just before or after Judge Jackson, indicated there was, on a $15,000 account, $5,000 was totally unaccounted for.

[Robert Penta]: No receipts, no records, totally unaccounted for.

[Robert Penta]: Now I know I see one of the folks sitting in the audience, I don't know which one it is, but I know he came to the podium one night and he said it was a combination of sloppy bookkeeping, not keeping the records accurate, but we're going to do a better job and all of that.

[Robert Penta]: Well, our resolution last week was to ask for an audit, a complete audit on channel three for the last three years and have that forwarded to the city because the rate payers really have no other alternative.

[Robert Penta]: but to either go to the mirror.

[Robert Penta]: And it's obvious that the mirror is either failing to do anything, doesn't want to do anything, afraid to do something.

[Robert Penta]: So the people's voice, which is at this podium right now, is nothing more than asking, what is really going on over there?

[Robert Penta]: You know, why would you want to put a TV station for cable subscribers for public access at a location that has no accessibility to the cable?

[Robert Penta]: That's number one.

[Robert Penta]: Number two, why wasn't that thought out ahead of time

[Robert Penta]: to know that cable access could not go there.

[Robert Penta]: There should be a credit coming back.

[Robert Penta]: People are getting paid for doing no work, because there's no work to be done over there, and there's no broadcasting.

[Robert Penta]: accessed in and out of one place.

[Robert Penta]: That Mr. Ramirez be invited down, who was a wonderful asset,

[Robert Penta]: at the Brookline Bank and he just retired.

[Robert Penta]: 13-449.

[Robert Penta]: It was laid in the table on the 14th.

[Robert Penta]: We get a report back on that.

[Robert Penta]: Yeah.

[Robert Penta]: I don't understand that.
